snippet: The fact that alcohol dissipates from the bloodstream over time does not by itself allow the police to take blood over objections, the Supreme Court ruled.
abstract: Supreme Court rules that police do not have right to draw blood without warrant in drunken-driving investigations.
lead_paragraph: The fact that alcohol dissipates from the bloodstream over time does not by itself allow the police to take blood over objections, the Supreme Court ruled.

headline.seo: Court Requires Warrants to Draw Blood in Drunken-Driving Cases
headline.main: Court Says Police Need Warrant for Blood Test
headline.print_headline: Court Says Police Need Warrant For Blood Test
